ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the course's primary purpose (as is) is to give FES students a taste of land use issues to entice them to take more courses in the subject. I was very familiar with the subjects discussed before taking the course, so I was hoping to get the land use perspective on issues I generally hear from different perspectives. i think the best part of the class is that I can look back on the slides and find a checklist of strategies that I may want to look up if I'm writing/working on a project that fits under one of the subjects. However, I did not find the lectures engaging. Perhaps if students were asked to each bring case studies for one class, choosing which they wrote the paper about in advance, it could help make the classes more engaging. The case studies that were presented felt very limited in their spectrum (generally cities of the same size in the CT-NY corridor), and it would have been nice to get students to bring their perspective through examples from across the nation/globe.

9) Professor Nolon loves student participation. He is enthusiastic about what he teaches, and is excited to engage student questions and talk about whatever topics students are interested in. 12) I was not familiar with this topic before taking the class and thought it would be more about land management rather than zoning and urban planning. For students interested in land management this class may not be very valuable, but to anyone interested in local government ordinances and zoning and planning, this class seems like it'd be quite valuable.

Professor Nolon can get really long winded at times. The quality of teaching is not up to par since there lacks eye contact and student participation. However the range of information covered is still useful. Ms. Jessica Bacher also shares the same style of teaching. Overall, it is difficult to learn and absorb knowledge given the issues of the existing pedagogy.
This course felt mainly taught by Jessica Bacher due to John's health problems. She was a very clear and effective communicator, and was very responsive to student's questions.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I liked our virtual field trip--I learned a lot!
Understanding how land management and policy can be used to effectively enhance carbon sequestration efforts and boost greenhouse gas mitigation.
Professors' enthusiasm
general exposure to land use planning for students that don't have space to commit to 3/4-credit course
The lecturers are friendly. The workload is minimum.
The field trip.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think we could have more discussion in this class.
The professor addressed this course as an after thought. This class was an outline of Prof. Nolon's work and not an exploration of land use issues. It was limited and not helpful.
Course lecture could be more dynamic and engaging.
the professor's lectures were not very engaging - he would read off very text-heavy slides.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: After being very excited about the land use and management tract at FES, this course has made me question whether or not I need to change my direction. If the other professors in the concentration give the same level of attention, students will be wasting their time.
I plan to pursue the sustainable land use specialization and this course was a good introduction to concepts discussed throughout this track.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: As a review of land use law and policy, as well as a foundational land use course requirement.
I thought this course would be a good introduction to land use planning concepts.
I thought it was going to be about managing land for different uses.
To get an introduction to some of the concepts in land use planning.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No - I thought it was going to be about managing land for different uses, but it was about zoning and urban planning. It was my fault for not looking closely enough into what land use planning really meant - now I know!
Yes.
Yes. It is a very broad overview course, which is what I expected from the 1 credit commitment.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read and actually participate in discussions! You will learn a lot more that way.
I think this course would be most valuable with some background knowledge of land use planning concepts.
Definitely take it if you have some background and interest in local land use law, zoning, sustainable urban planning or architecture. If not, this may not be the most interesting course for you.
take an actual course on land use planning if possible. this is no substitute, just a teaser/introduction.
This is a very good course for gaining initial exposure to the field of land use planning, but the course doesn't go very far beyond that.
